verses.text: Now Elijah the Tishbite, from Tishbe in Gilead, said to Ahab, 'As the LORD, the God of Israel, lives, before whom I stand, there will not be dew or rain these years, except at my word.'
verses.comment: Preserves word order and references Elijah's prophetic authority.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to him, saying,
verses.comment: Follows traditional rendering of prophetic revelation.

verses.text: 'Leave here, turn eastward, and hide yourself by the brook Cherith, which is east of the Jordan.'
verses.comment: Stays true to geographic detail and imperative phrasing.

verses.text: 'You shall drink from the brook, and I have commanded the ravens to feed you there.'
verses.comment: Uses direct address; 'commanded' reflects Hebrew verb.

verses.text: So he went and did according to the word of the LORD. He went and lived by the brook Cherith, which is east of the Jordan.
verses.comment: Repeats for clarity, as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and bread and meat in the evening, and he drank from the brook.
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew pattern.

verses.text: After a while the brook dried up, because there was no rain in the land.
verses.comment: 'After a while' captures 'at the end of days' in simple modern English.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to him, saying,
verses.comment: Repetition as in the original.

verses.text: 'Get up, go to Zarephath, which belongs to Sidon, and stay there. I have commanded a widow there to provide for you.'
verses.comment: 'Provide for you' interprets 'to sustain you.'

verses.text: So he got up and went to Zarephath. When he came to the gate of the city, there was a widow gathering sticks. He called to her and said, 'Please bring me a little water in a vessel, that I may drink.'
verses.comment: 'Please' reflects politeness present in the Hebrew.

verses.text: As she was going to get it, he called to her and said, 'Please bring me a piece of bread in your hand.'

But she said, 'As the LORD your God lives, I have no bread, only a handful of flour in a jar and a little oil in a jug. See, I am gathering a couple of sticks so I can go in and prepare it for myself and my son, so we may eat it and die.'
verses.comment: Literal translation; preserves her oath formula.

verses.text: Elijah said to her, 'Do not be afraid. Go and do as you have said. But first make a small cake for me from it and bring it out to me. Afterward, make some for yourself and your son.'
verses.comment: 'Cake' reflects traditional Hebrew flatbread.

verses.text: For thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: 'The jar of flour will not be used up, and the jug of oil will not run dry, until the day the LORD sends rain on the land.'
verses.comment: Literal to the Hebrew declaration.

verses.text: She went and did as Elijah said, and she and her household ate for many days.
verses.comment: 'Household' clarifies the Hebrew collective.

verses.text: The jar of flour was not used up, nor did the jug of oil run dry, according to the word of the LORD spoken by Elijah.
verses.comment: Direct rendering of the miraculous provision.

verses.text: After these things, the son of the woman, the mistress of the house, became sick. His illness was so severe that he stopped breathing.
verses.comment: 'Stopped breathing' modernizes 'no breath left in him.'

verses.text: She said to Elijah, 'What have you against me, man of God? Have you come to remind me of my sin and cause my son’s death?'
verses.comment: Stays close to original idiom.

verses.text: But he said to her, 'Give me your son.' So he took him from her arms, carried him up to the room where he was staying, and laid him on his own bed.
He cried out to the LORD and said, 'O LORD my God, have you brought tragedy even upon this widow with whom I stay, by causing her son to die?'
verses.comment: 'Causing her son to die' interprets the literal Hebrew, 'to kill her son.'

verses.text: He stretched himself out three times upon the child and cried to the LORD, 'O LORD my God, let this child's life return to him!'
verses.comment: Repetition reflects the exact actions.

verses.text: The LORD heard the voice of Elijah, and the child’s life returned to him, and he lived.
verses.comment: 'Life' reflects Hebrew 'soul.'

verses.text: Elijah took the child, brought him down from the upper room into the house, and gave him to his mother. Elijah said, 'See, your son lives.'
verses.comment: 'See' renders the Hebrew 'Behold.'

verses.text: Then the woman said to Elijah, 'Now I know that you are a man of God and that the word of the LORD in your mouth is truth.'
verses.comment: "Truth" preserves certainty in her declaration.
